title: Question 1 - 1.4.4
text: Given `f(x)= x^2 + 2x` and `g(x)= 6-x^2`, find `f+g`, `f-g`, `fg`, and `f/g`. Determine the domain for each function in interval notation.
options: `(f+g)(x)= 2x+6`, domain: `(-oo, oo)`; `(f - g)(x) = 2 x ^ 2 + 2 x - 6`, domain: `(-oo, oo)`; `(fg)(x) = -x ^ 4 - 2 x ^ 3 + 6 x ^ 2 + 12 x`, domain: `(-oo, oo)`; `(f / g)(x) = (x ^ 2 + 2 x) / (6 - x ^ 2)`, domain: `(-oo, -sqrt(6)) uu(-sqrt(6), sqrt(6)) uu(sqrt(6), oo)`

`(f+g)(x) = 2x+6`, domain: `(-oo, oo)`; `(f-g)(x)= 2x^2 + 2x -6`, domain: `(-oo, oo)`; `(fg)(x)= 6x^2-2x^3`, domain: `(-oo, oo)`; `(f/g) (x)= (x^2+2x)/(6-x^2)`, domain: `(-oo, -sqrt(6)) uu (-sqrt(6), sqrt(6)) uu (sqrt(6), oo)`

title: Question 1 - 2.1.6
text: At noon, a barista notices that they have `$20` in their tip jar. If the barista makes an average of `$0.50` from each customer, how much will they have in the tip jar if they serve n more customers during the shift?

title: Question 2 - 2.1.6
text: A gym membership with two personal training sessions costs `$125`, while gym membership with five personal training sessions costs `$260`. What is the cost per session?

title: Question 3 - 2.1.6
text: A farmer finds there is a linear relationship between the number of beanstalks, `n`, she plants and the yield, `y`, each plant produces. When she plants `30` stalks, each plant yields `30` oz of beans. When she plants `34` stalks, each plant produces `28` oz of beans. Find a linear relationship in the form `y=mn+b` that gives the yield when `n` stalks are planted.

title: Question 4 - 2.1.6
text: A town’s population has been growing linearly. In 2003, the population was `45,000`, and the population has been growing by `1,700` people each year. Write an equation, `P(t)`, for the population `t` years after 2003.

title: Question 1 - 2.2.6
text: A rectangle is formed by a set of four intersecting lines. Two of the intersecting lines are given by the equations `2x-3y=8` and `3x+2y=6`. If one of the remaining two lines has equation `4x-6y=25`, which one of the following is the equation of the fourth line?

title: Question 2 - 2.2.6
text: Two lines form adjacent sides of a rectangle. One of them has an equation `6x+5y=1`. What should be the value of the constant `b` in the line equation `3x+by=6` for it to form the adjacent side?

title: Question 3 - 2.2.6
text: The function `f(x)=2x-3` has an inverse `f^{-1}(x)=(x+3)/2`. State true or false with respect to this example: The lines perpendicular to the graphs of functions `f(x)` and `f^{-1}(x)` are perpendicular to each other.

title: Question 4 - 2.2.6
text: A line `y=x` is stretched vertically by a factor of 3 to form Line1. The same line `y=x` is stretched horizontally by a factor of 3 and then reflected in the `x`-axis to form Line2. State true or false: Line1 and Line2 are perpendicular to each other.

title: Question 5 - 2.2.6
text: Find the equation of a line parallel to the line `y=2/3x+5/3` and passing through the point `(3,-2)`. Then select from among the following points, the one through which it passes.

title: Question 6 - 2.2.6
text: Find the equation of a line perpendicular to the line `y=2/3x+5/3` and passing through the point `(3,-2)`. Then select from among the following points, the one through which it passes.

title: Question 7 - 2.2.6
text: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides that are parallel. Line1 with equation `5x-2y=7` and Line2 with equation `8x+3y=5` form two adjacent sides of a parallelogram. They intersect at one vertex `(1,-1)` . The vertex of the parallelogram diagonally opposite to this vertex is `(-3,2)` . Which of the following pairs of lines will form the remaining two sides of that parallelogram?

title: Question 8 - 2.2.6
text: A parallelogram is a quadrilateral with both pairs of opposite sides that are parallel. Line1 with equation `5x=7` and Line2 with equation `8x+3y=5`  form two adjacent sides of a parallelogram. They intersect at one vertex `(7/5,-31/15)`. The vertex of the parallelogram diagonally opposite to this vertex is `(-3/5,2/5)`. Which of the following lines must form one of the remaining two sides of that parallelogram?

title: Question 9 - 2.2.6
text: The endpoints of the diagonal of a rectangle are `(2,-3)` and `(-3,5)`. The sides of the rectangle are parallel to the coordinate axes. Which of the following line equations cannot form a side of the rectangle?

title: Question 10 - 2.2.6
text: Which of the following lines cannot be parallel to the line with equation `2/3x+5/6y=2`?

title: Question 11 - 2.2.6
text: Which of the following lines cannot be perpendicular to the line with equation `2/3x+5/6y=2`?

title: Question 1 - 2.2.7
text: Find the point of intersection of the pair of lines if it exists. If it does not exist, indicate that there is no point of intersection. `x-2y+2=3, x-y=3`

title: Question 2 - 2.2.7
text: Find the point of intersection of the pair of lines if it exists. If it does not exist, indicate that there is no point of intersection. `2x-3y=12, 5y+x=30`

title: Question 3 - 2.2.7
text: Find the point of intersection of the pair of lines if it exists. If it does not exist, indicate that there is no point of intersection. `5x+3y=-65, x-y=-5`

title: Question 4 - 2.2.7
text: Find the point of intersection of the pair of lines if it exists. If it does not exist, indicate that there is no point of intersection. `y=3/4x+1,-3x+4y=12`

title: Question 5 - 2.2.7
text: Find the point of intersection of the pair of lines if it exists. If it does not exist, indicate that there is no point of intersection. `2x = y – 3, y + 4x = 15`

title: Question 1 - 2.3.2
text: As an independent seller on Ebay a college student sells items of jewelry for `$25.00` per item.  The cost  to make each item is `$4.00`,  Furthermore, the Ebay fees and postage cost `$2.70` for each piece of jewelry produced. a.Write a linear cost function to produce `x` items of jewelry. b.Write a linear revenue function for selling `x`items of jewelry. c.Write a linear profit function for producing and selling `x` items of jewelry. d.How much profit will the college student make if `100` items of jewelry are produced and sold ? e.How much profit will be made for producing and selling `200` items ? f.How much profit or loss is made if the student makes `10` display items of jewelry and gets no orders that week ?
options: a) `C(x) = 6.70x`, b) `R(x) = 25x` , c) `P(x) = 18.30x` , d) The student will make `$1830` profit, e)The student will make `$3660`, f) The student will lose `$67`.
a) `C(x) = 4x`, b) `R(x) = 25x`, c)` P(x) = 21x`. d) The student will make `$2100` profit., e) The student will make `$4200`, f) The student will lose `$40`.
a) `C(x) = 4x`, b) `R(x) = 27.70x`, c) `P(x) = 23.70x`, d) The student will make `$2370` profit, e) The student will make `$4740`. f) The student will lose `$40`.

title: Question 2 - 2.3.2
text: You are choosing between two different prepaid cell phone plans. The first plan charges a rate of `26` cents per minute. The second plan charges a monthly fee of `$19.95` plus `11` cents per minute. How many minutes would you have to use in a month in order for the second plan to be preferable?

title: Question 3 - 2.3.2
text: You are choosing between two different window washing companies. The first charges `$5` per window. The second charges a base fee of `$40` plus `$3` per window. How many windows would you need to have for the second company to be preferable?

title: Question 4 - 2.3.2
text: When hired at a new job selling jewelry, you are given two pay options: Option `A`: Base salary of `$17,000` a year with a commission of `12%` of your sales Option `B`: Base salary of `$20,000` a year with a commission of `5%` of your sales How much jewelry would you need to sell for option `A` to produce a larger income ?

title: Question 5 - 2.3.2
text: When hired at a new job selling electronics, you are given two pay options: Option `A`: Base salary of `$20,000` a year with a commission of `12%` of your sales Option `B`: Base salary of `$26,000` a year with a commission of `3%` of your sales How much electronics would you need to sell for option `A` to produce a larger income ?

title: Question 6 - 2.3.2
text: When hired at a new job selling electronics, you are given two pay options: Option `A`: Base salary of `$10,000` a year with a commission of `9%` of your sales Option `B`: Base salary of `$20,000` a year with a commission of `4%` of your sales. How much electronics would you need to sell for option `A` to produce a larger income ?

title: Question 1 - 6.2.6
text: For the following function, sketch two periods of the graph for each of the following functions. Identify the stretching factor, period, and asymptotes. `f(x)=-3 cot(2x)`
options: Stretching factor: `3`, Period: `pi/2` and Asymptotes: `pi/2 k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching Factor: `-3`, Period: `pi` and Asymptotes: `pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `2`, Period: `2` and Asymptotes: `2pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `2x`, Period: `1/2` and Asymptotes: `pi/4 k` where `k` is an integer

title: Question 2 - 6.2.6
text: For the following function, sketch two periods of the graph for each of the following functions. Identify the stretching factor, period, and asymptotes. `f(x)= 5cot((x+ pi/2) -3)`
options: Stretching factor: `5`, Period: `pi` and Asymptotes: `(3- pi/2)+pik` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching Factor: `-3`, Period: `pi/2 -3` and Asymptotes: `(-3+ pi/2) + pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `pi/2`, Period: `2pi` and Asymptotes: `-pi/2 + 2pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `pi/2 -3`, Period: `5` and Asymptotes: `(3pi)/2+ pi k` where `k` is an integer

title: Question 3 - 6.2.6
text: For the following function, sketch two periods of the graph for each of the following functions. Identify the stretching factor, period, and asymptotes. `f(x)= -sec(x- pi/3) -2`.
options: Stretching factor: `1`, Period: `2pi` and Asymptotes: `pi/3 + pi/2 k` where `k` is an odd integer.
Stretching Factor: `-1`, Period: `pi/2`  and Asymptotes: `pi/3 + pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `-2`, Period: `pi/3` and Asymptotes: `-pi/3 + pi/2 k` where `k` is an odd integer.
Stretching factor: `pi/3`, Period: `pi` and Asymptotes: `(-pi)/3 -2 + pi/2 k` where `k` is an integer

title: Question 4 - 6.2.6
text: For the following function, sketch two periods of the graph for each of the following functions. Identify the stretching factor, period, and asymptotes. `f(x) = 2csc(x+ pi/4) -1
options: Stretching factor: `2`, Period: `2pi` and Asymptotes: `-pi/4 + pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching Factor: `1`, Period: `pi/2`  and Asymptotes: `pi/4 + pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `-1`, Period: `pi` and Asymptotes: `-pi/4 -1 + pi k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `pi/4`, Period: `pi/4` and Asymptotes: `-pi/8+ pi/2 k` where `k` is an integer

title: Question 5 - 6.2.6
text: For the following function, sketch two periods of the graph for each of the following functions. Identify the stretching factor, period, and asymptotes. `f(x)= 6csc(pi/3 x + pi)`.
options: Stretching factor: `6`, Period: `6` and Asymptotes: `3k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching Factor: `-(2pi)/3`, Period: `2pi`  and Asymptotes: `-3 + 3k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `pi/3`, Period: `pi` and Asymptotes: `pi + pi/2 k` where `k` is an integer.
Stretching factor: `pi`, Period: `(4pi)/3` and Asymptotes: `pi/3 -2 + pi k` where `k` is odd an integer

title: Question 1 - 6.2.7
text: The function `f(x) = 20tan(pi 10x)` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `x`, in seconds, and distance `f(x)`, in feet. Evaluate `f(1)` and `f(2.5)` and discuss the function’s values at those inputs.
options: `f(1)=0` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `1`, in seconds and `f(2.5)=0` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `2.5`, in seconds.

`f(1)=12.967` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `1`, in seconds and `f(2.5)-2.671` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `2.5`, in seconds.

`f(1)=0` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `1`, in seconds and `f(2.5)=6.667 * 10^(-13)` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `2.5`, in seconds.

`f(1)=`undefined means the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall cannot be calculated at `1` second `f(2.5)=`undefined means the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall cannot be calculated at `2.5` seconds

title: Question 2 - 6.2.7
text: Standing on the shore of a lake, a fisherman sights a boat far in the distance to his left. Let `x`, measured in radians, be the angle formed by the line of sight to the ship and a line due north from his position. Assume due north is 0 and 𝑥 is measured negative to the left and positive to the right. (See Figure 19) The boat travels from due west to due east and, ignoring the curvature of the Earth, the distance `d(x)`, in kilometers, from the fisherman to the boat is given by the function `d(x)=1.5sec(x)`. (a) What is a reasonable domain for `d(x)`? (b) Find and discuss the meaning of any vertical asymptotes on the graph of `d(x)`. (c) Calculate and interpret `d(−pi/3)`. Round to the second decimal place.(d) Calculate and interpret `d(pi/6)`.Round to the second decimal place.(e) What is the minimum distance between the fisherman and the boat? When does this occur?
options: a) `(-pi/2, pi/2)`, b) `x= -pi/2` and `x=pi/2`; the distance grows without bound as `abs(x)` approaches `pi/2` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c) `3` km; when `x = -pi/3` the fisherman is `3` km to the west of the boat. d) `1.73` km; when `x = pi/6` the boat is `1.73` km away. e) `1.5` km when `x=0`.

a) `(-pi/2, (3pi)/2)` b) `x= -pi/2` and `x= (3pi)/2`; the distance grows without bound as approaches `(3pi)/2` or `-pi/2` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c) `30` km; when `x= -pi/3` the fisherman is `30` km away from the boat. d) `2` km; when `x=pi/6` the boat is `2` km away. e) `2` km; when `x= pi/6`.

a) `(-pi, pi)` b) `x= -pi` and `x= pi`; the distance grows without bound as `abs(x)` approaches `pi` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c)  `1.5` km; when `x= -pi/3` the fisherman is `1.5` km away from the boat. d) `1.5` km; when `x= pi/6` the boat is `1.5` km away. e) `1.5` km when `x=-pi/3` and `x= pi/6`

a) `(-2pi, 2pi)` b) `x= -2pi` and `x= 2pi`; the distance grows without bound as `abs(x)` approaches `2pi` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c)  `3` km; when `x= -pi/3` the fisherman is `3` km away from the boat. d) `0` km; when `x=2pi` the boat is `0` km away. e) `0` km; when `x=2pi`

title: Question 3 - 6.2.7
text: A laser rangefinder is locked on a comet approaching Earth. The distance `g(x)`, in kilometers, of the comet after `x` days, for `x` in the interval `0` to `30` days, is given by `g(x)= 250,000 csc(pi/(30) x)`. Evaluate `g(5)` and interpret the information.
options: `g(5)=500,000`. The comet is `500,000` kilometers from the Earth after `5` days.
`g(5)= undefined`. The comet is too far away for the rangefinder to find it after `5` days.
`g(5)=0`. The comet hits the Earth after `5` days.
`g(5)=500`. The comet is `500` kilometers from the Earth after `5` days.

title: Question 4 - 6.2.7
text: A video camera is focused on a rocket on a launching pad `2` miles from the camera. The angle of elevation from the ground to the rocket after `x` seconds `pi 120x`. a) Write a function expressing the altitude `h(x)`, in miles, of the rocket above the ground after `x` seconds. Ignore the curvature of the Earth. b) Evaluate and interpret the values `h(0)` and `h(30)`. c) What happens to the values of `h(x)` as `x` approaches `60` seconds? Interpret the meaning of this in terms of the problem.
options: a) `h(x) = 2tan(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=0` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is `0` miles above the ground or in other words, the rocket launches from ground level; `h(30)=2` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `2` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` grow infinitely large. The distance to the rocket is growing so large that the camera can no longer track it.

a) `h(x) = 2cos(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=2` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is `2` miles above the ground; `h(30)=1.41` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `1.41` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` decrease as the rocket comes back to Earth.

a) `h(x) = 2csc(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=undefined` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is too far away to be tracked by the camera; `h(30)=3` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `3` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` decrease as the rocket comes back to Earth.

a) `h(x) = 2sec(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=2` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is `2` miles above the ground; `h(30)=2.82` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `2.82` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` grow increasingly large. The distance to the rocket is growing so large that the camera can no longer track it.
